Orion

You're confusing Marxism with stalinism.
 
 
 
Nope. I'm intimately familiar with Marxist-Leninist Communism, and there's little that's voluntary about it.

 
 Karl Marx envisioned that his socio-political-economic system would evolve, over time, from the nineteenth century capitalism of his day. According to Marx, this system would be driven almost entirely by the volunteerism of the 'New Social Man'. For example, factory managers would no longer be necessary because the workers would run the factories themselves. Workers would produce goods and services with the sole intent of adding to the common good. Financial profit from the sale of these goods/services and the exploitation of workers would cease to be a consideration. The power of the police would diminish in that most crimes involving money or material goods would cease to exist. Indeed, according to Marx, the state, itself, along with its coercive powers, would eventually be seen as unnecessary and would disappear altogether. Lenin didn't have a clue as to how to bring this about, and what Stalin put into place bore no resemblance to what Marx had in mind. 
 
 Was Marx an idealist? Of course, as was Jesus. Marx overestimated the selflessness of man and failed to recognize the economic and social reforms which would emerge from nineteenth century European society in response to the effects of unbridled capitalism, not the least of which would be the rise of organized labour as well as legislated social reforms regarding child labour, working conditions, and social safety nets. However, most of this becomes academic when you consider that America has become deeply indebted to Asians, who produce great quantities of the goodies purchased by Americans. We pay for those goodies with dollars, and the Asians turn around and lend those dollars to the Fed so as to balance the domestic budget deficit. Cute. Asians are also buying American dollars in an attempt to prop up the value of the dollar so as to protect their export markets. How long they will continue to do this is anyone's guess.

 God clearly has given a different level of service to the man which he has not designated for women. "But I would have you know, that the head of every man is Christ; and the head of the woman is the man; and the head of Christ is God" (I Cor 11:3). Therefore the order given is God, Christ, man, woman. Submission is not a sign of inferiority. If it were, our Lord Jesus would be inferior to God the Father. But we read in Phil. 2:6 where Jesus "thought it not robbery to be equal with God." But he was submissive to the Father for we read: "For I came down from heaven, not to do mine own will, but the will of him that sent me" (John 6:38). By the same reasoning, woman is not inferior because God has assigned her a different role in the church to the role of man. (Geocities.com)

Seems like you think you know better than God, Orion.

 
 No, actually, I was commenting on the writings of Paul. 
 
 
As Paul stated, it wasn't the man (Adam) who was deceived by Satan in the Garden of Eden, but the woman.

 
 Yes, I understand mythology for what it is, especially to the extent that it can shape opinion, especially in this case, the opinions of Paul concerning women. 
 
 
God clearly has given a different level of service to the man which he has not designated for women. "But I would have you know, that the head of every man is Christ; and the head of the woman is the man; and the head of Christ is God" (I Cor 11:3). Therefore the order given is God, Christ, man, woman. Submission is not a sign of inferiority. If it were, our Lord Jesus would be inferior to God the Father. But we read in Phil. 2:6 where Jesus "thought it not robbery to be equal with God." But he was submissive to the Father for we read: "For I came down from heaven, not to do mine own will, but the will of him that sent me" (John 6:38). By the same reasoning, woman is not inferior because God has assigned her a different role in the church to the role of man. (Geocities.com) 
 
 Now I'm sure you'd rather have your Barbara Boxers and Hillary Clintons and (liberal theologian) Elaine Pagels all suit up in the pulpit and tell us how the government and man's (alleged) inherent "goodness" will save people, but I think you need to go back to square one and rethink your folly.

 
 Thank you for sharing that with us, EZ. Can I take it from this that you oppose women being allowed to serve as teachers, police officers, court judges, legislators, or as mayor or governor? Again I ask, would you take supervision from a woman in the workplace? Not that I'm pushing the issue, but I'd like your opinion.
Easyrider

Yes, I understand mythology for what it is, especially to the extent that it can shape opinion, especially in this case, the opinions of Paul concerning women.

 
 Your divine beliefs are the mythology, Orion, not mine. You've never been able in the slightest to document yours. 
 
 
 Thank you for sharing that with us, EZ. Can I take it from this that you oppose women being allowed to serve as teachers, police officers, court judges, legislators, or as mayor or governor? Again I ask, would you take supervision from a woman in the workplace? Not that I'm pushing the issue, but I'd like your opinion.

 
 How many times over the years are you going to ask this stupid question?
 
 Already answered in previous fora over the years for you personally.
 
 Now go and pray to Jesus so he can enlighten you.
